questions.question: Why do factories prefer Magnesium Hydroxide over Sodium Hydroxide for treating acidic lake water?

options.option: It turns the water into a better fuel source.
Its low solubility prevents the pH from accidentally rising too high (over-alkalizing).
It is a liquid that dissolves faster than any other base.
It adds oxygen to the water for the fish to breathe.

questions.answer: B (Magnesium Hydroxide is self-limiting and prevents over-alkalization, unlike Sodium Hydroxide).

questions.question: As food moves from the stomach to the small intestine, the environment must shift from pH 2 to pH 8. What is the main reason for this neutralization?

options.option: To stop the food from moving too quickly.
To allow intestinal enzymes to function and prevent "burning" the intestine wall.
To help the body store more acid for later use.
To kill off all beneficial gut bacteria.

questions.answer: B (Enzymes in the small intestine require an alkaline environment to function).

questions.question: In nanomaterial synthesis, the exothermic nature of neutralization is its most valuable trait. What does this mean in a practical sense?

options.option: The reaction absorbs heat from the room to stay cold.
The reaction creates a vacuum.
The reaction releases the heat energy needed to transform metal precursors.
The reaction creates a magnetic field.

questions.answer: C (Exothermic reactions release heat energy, which can be useful in synthesis).

questions.question: In a titration, you know neutralization is complete at the Equivalence Point, but you visually see this happen when the pH indicator __________.

options.option: decreases pH
increases temperature
increases molality
changes color

questions.answer: D (Indicators change color at the endpoint).

questions.question: Farmers use Calcium Carbonate to treat "sour" soil because it neutralizes the acid and releases __________ gas as a byproduct.

options.option: Carbon trioxide
Carbon dioxide
Carbon monoxide
Limestone

questions.answer: B (Carbon dioxide is released when carbonates react with acids).
